WebVR app using A-Frame, large regular hexagon tile in blue
Make sure everything is in a single HTML file with embedded CSS and JS in a single code block to be used as a web app.

Sure! Below is a simple web app using A-Frame that creates a large regular hexagon tile in blue. The entire code is embedded in a single HTML file with CSS and JavaScript. You can copy and paste this code into an HTML file and open it in a compatible browser to see it in action.

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>WebVR Hexagon Tile</title>
    <script src="https://aframe.io/releases/1.2.0/aframe.min.js"></script>
    <style>
        body {
            margin: 0;
            overflow: hidden;
        }
        a-scene {
            height: 100vh;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    <a-scene>
        <a-entity camera look-controls position="0 1.6 3"></a-entity>
        <a-light type="directional" color="#FFFFFF" position="-1 2 1"></a-light>
        <a-entity id="hexagon" geometry="primitive: hexagon; radius: 1.5" material="color: blue" rotation="0 0 0" position="0 0 -5"></a-entity>
        <a-sky color="#ECECEC"></a-sky>
    </a-scene>
</body>
</html>
```

### Explanation:
- **A-Frame Library**: The code includes the A-Frame library from a CDN, which is required for rendering 3D content.
- **Hexagon**: The hexagon is created using the A-Frame `<a-entity>` with a `geometry` component set to `primitive: hexagon` and a `radius` of 1.5.
- **Material**: It is assigned a blue color using the `material` component.
- **Camera**: A camera is positioned to allow for a VR experience.
- **Lighting**: A directional light is added to illuminate the hexagon.
- **Sky**: The background of the scene is set to a light grey color.

To view the WebVR app, open the HTML file in a browser like Chrome or Firefox that supports WebXR. You can also use WebVR headsets for an immersive experience.

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">

<body>
    <a-scene>
        <a-entity camera look-controls position="0 1.6 5"></a-entity>
        <a-light type="directional" color="#FFFFFF" position="-1 2 1"></a-light>
        <a-entity geometry="primitive: hexagon; radius: 2.5" material="color: blue" position="0 0 -5"></a-entity>

    </a-scene>
```

### Explanation:
- **HTML Structure**: The document has a simplified structure with the necessary `head` and `body` sections.
- **A-Frame Script**: The A-Frame library is included via a CDN link.
- **CSS Styles**: Styles are embedded to ensure no margin and set the height of the A-Frame scene to fill the viewport.
- **Scene Elements**:
  - **Camera**: An entity with a camera and look-controls is positioned to view the hexagon.
  - **Light**: A directional light is added to illuminate the hexagon.
  - **Hexagon**: The hexagon tile is created with a geometry component set to `primitive: hexagon` with a radius of `2.5` and a blue color.
  - **Sky**: The sky is configured with a light grey color for contrast.

### Usage:
Copy the entire code snippet above into a new HTML file (e.g., `hexagon.html`) and open it with a modern web browser that supports WebVR, such as Google Chrome or Firefox. You will be able to view and interact with the hexagon in a virtual environment.
